Message.Title: Military Times Survey: 75% of Troops Oppose Strikes On Syria
Message.Msg: Military Times Survey: 75% of Troops Oppose Strikes On Syria Mike Krieger Liberty Blitzkrieg September 14, 2013 It’s always a good sign for an empire’s fortunes when the commander in chief of the armed forces completely loses the confidence and trust of the troops. While we have all seen various polls demonstrating the general public’s complete opposition to unprovoked military aggression against Syria, I hadn’t seen a survey focused on military members until now. The results are not good for the establishment. From the Military Times: To the list of skeptics who question the need for air strikes against Syria, add an another unlikely group — many U.S. troops. “I haven’t heard one single person be supportive of it,” said an Army staff sergeant at Fort Hood who asked not to be identified by name. A Military Times survey of more than 750 active-duty troops this week found service members oppose military action in Syria by a margin of about three to one. The survey conducted online Monday and Tuesday found that about 75 percent of troops are not in favor of air strikes in response to reports that the Syrian government used chemical weapons to kill civilians in that country.

Message.Msg: Being ex Air Force and a former avionics tech on the C-5, C-141 and KC-135 in my Air Force years, Boeing is going to make some serious coin on the 767 tanker program over the next 20 years. Message.Msg: Boeing Co. will have to absorb as much as $700 million in cost overruns on the refueling tanker the company is developing for the U.S. Air Force, about $300 million more than previously estimated, according to the military service. Boeing, which is developing the KC-46A tanker using its 767 commercial airliner, is responsible for all costs exceeding the development-stage contract’s $4.9 billion ceiling, the Air Force said. Next the contract is fixed so any over cost is paid by Boeing shareholders , not the government and we all know the 787 a hard money job is several billion over cost, no reason to think MD outsourcing will make a very slim profit margin , all bowing wanted to do was keep the better plane Airbus out. So the 767 will never make a dime in profit. Airbus made sure by making a very low bid to do the job , in effect killing any profit for bowing then backing out and laughing while they develop their factory for their highly profitable civilian plane on Americn soil d-pooch we are glad you are our of the air force now your too stupid to be on the GI pay. The new, higher estimate was disclosed in response to an inquiry about the latest cost projections for what’s planned as a 179-aircraft, $51.7 billion program including research, production and aircraft support. “The government’s projection of Boeing’s potential liability has increased to about $700 million,” Air Force spokesman Charles Gulick said in a statement. “Government liability is capped,” and any additional “financial liability is completely borne by Boeing.” The Air Force said its estimate of the cost to complete the development contract is $5.6 billion, up from the $5.3 billion projected in 2011 in the service’s annual cost report to Congress. Chicago-based Boeing estimates the cost at $5.1 billion, according to the serv

Topic.Title: Airbus stock price increase year to date 51% Boeing 47%, 3 years Airbus up 144%,Boeing loser at only76%

Message.Msg: Here is the definition of earnings per share and the second sentance isn't mine In a given fiscal year, a publicly-traded company's profit divided by the number of shares outstanding. This is considered the single most important aspect in determining a share's price and value, because the calculation of earnings per share shows the amount of money to which a shareholder would be entitled in the event of the company's liquidation. In general, earnings per share applies only to common shares

Message.Msg: A400M- sound familiar? On 29 March 2009, Airbus CEO Thomas Enders told Der Spiegel magazine that the program may need to be abandoned without changes.[21] Then on 3 April 2009 the South African Air Force announced that it would start considering alternatives to the A400M due to postponed production and increased cost.[22] On 5 November 2009, South Africa announced it was cancelling the order citing increased cost and delivery delays.[23] On 12 June, The New York Times reported that Germany and France have delayed the decision whether or not to cancel their orders for another six months, while the UK still plans to decide at the end of June. The NYT also quotes a report to the French Senate from February 2009, according to which "the A400M is €5 billion over budget, 3 to 4 years behind schedule, [...] aerospace experts estimate it is also costing Airbus between €1 billion and €1.5 billion a year."[24]

As I recall, the following occurred during Bush Jr.'s reign of idiocy. - Two wars, one of which was completely unnecessary and served to kill several thousand U.S. military personnel, tens if not hundreds of thousands of innocent Iraqi civilians and greatly increased Iran's power and influence in the Middle East. - The botched apprehension of Osama bin Laden, after which Bush suggested to the American people that bringing bin Laden to justice wasn't really all that important. The fact that it took a Democrat of all people to get bin Laden speaks volumes. - The near total collapse of the U.S. banking industry and the worst economic crisis since the Great Depression, which caused millions of Americans to lose their job, their home and wiped out trillions of dollars of American's wealth. - A massive expansion of Medicare via the Medicare Prescription Drug Program. I thought you guys hated that kind of thing. Apparently it's okay if a Republican does it. - Passage of sweeping tax cuts during wartime (1st time ever in U.S. history I believe), which erased a federal budget surplus that the Congressional Budget Office estimated would pay off the entire U.S. debt in less than a decade and that primarily benefited the wealthy. - Putting a "hack" with absolutely no disaster experience in charge of FEMA, which led to the botched response to hurricane Katrina. Yes, it was a truly great time to be an American. I think you've been spending too much time around Wayne.

Message.Title: Airbus tricked Boeing into a money drain on the tanker like they tricked Frank Schrontz into selling the 747-400 at a loss
Message.Msg: After Boeing won the tanker contract , annalists said it would be hard for Boeing to make money at its aggressive bid price. Some observers speculated that Boeing was willing to lose money on the tanker to block an Airbus assembly line that EADS subsidiary Airbus would have built in Mobile, Ala., if EADS North America won the tanker contract. That line could have made Airbus more competitive against Boeing commercial aircraft. well for the long term Boeing poster boys they missed , Ba did not block Airbus. Airbus herded Boeing into a no profit bleed the Boeing company out of money while Airbus did Build a plane that will make huge money for airbus in he USA 80% of Boeing profit is from civilian airplanes so this was a stupid move for Boeing in he first place another MD bad decision to lowball. And keep Airbus out of the USA fail

Message.Title: Great day for Airbus the only company to have assembly lines in America, Europe and Asia."
Message.Msg: After years of battling Boeing for commercial and military jet orders in the US, Airbus is taking the battle to American soil. It is breaking ground on its first US final assembly plant in Mobile, Ala. and many believe this is just the start of Airbus' expansion in America. "It is a great day for us," said , CEO of Airbus. "It means we will be the only company in the world having assembly lines in America, Europe and Asia."
Never had an accident that caused loss of life until a pilot made a bad landing. Tell me about quality! AirBus, eat your heart out!

Topic.Title: New question re syria

Message.Msg: it will take at least 5 to 10 years to destroy the supposed amount of WMD- so who will control them? UN ? search non umitila oregon Umatilla Chemical Depot located in Umatilla, OR, destroys chemical weapons and eliminates the threat from further storage. Storage and incineration facility for conventional and chemical weapons. Opened 1941. Originally established as a military supply depot for World War II, the facility was converted in 1962 to a munitions storage yard. The last munitions stored at this facility were destroyed on 2011 October 25. Base closure is expected to be completed in 2015.
That is truly an impressive record. The new 777x should knock their socks off as this plane is long overdue and with what should be a greatly efficient plane.

Topic.Title: Air Force 767 Tanker

Message.Msg: The tanker win was great. The program will be with Boeing for many years as more US and then international sales come in. Repair, maintenance, upgrades etc will insure a nice cash flow. Hope that new wing and new engine make it super efficient.
